ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to strengthen my skills as a writer and critical thinker in this class through the readings and assignments.
Lots of philosophical introspective thinking.
Plato's The Republic and additional philosophical discourse.
what is the purpose of college education? the entire class is designed for us to think critically about this question
I feel I have a solid grip on The Republic and particularly the portions of it commonly referenced such as the Nobel Lie and the Allegory of the Cave.
Critical reading and writing skills, how to consider concepts from various viewpoints, how to discuss these concepts
different philosophies about the purpose of college education

I would say that the thing I appreciate most about having taken this class is that now I have read Plato's Republic; that book is such a fundamental classic that you can find references to it in so so many different places. I just feel like a more generally educated person, which I guess is what the liberal arts system is trying to achieve with its distributional requirements.
I learned how to read and (semi)-understand the teachings of philosophers such as Plato and Aristotle.

I learned about the university's role in the formation of young people. It was interesting to learn about the different topics like community and conversation throughout the semester. I also enjoyed learning about debates that exist regarding the purpose of college education.
alot of self reflection
I developed an ability to analyze critically and use my writing ability to connect past events to the present.
Learned to question our motives behind being at college and Yale through a variety of literature, including Plato's Republic.
Certain philosophy skills that Ive never done before.
I greatly enjoyed this course. Improved my writing, critical thinking, and understanding of relevant popular issues
Helped me develop better communication and advocacy during discussion. I  worked on my in depth reading and analyzation skills. I also learned more about college and education itself.
I developed a better understanding of major ideas of Plato.
We got to learn a lot about older philosophies regarding education, including a pretty in depth overview of Platonic views
I learned about Yale's institutional purposes and history. I also learned a bit more about Yale students' prospects and how old philosophical teachings helped form Yale's ideology.
I learned the connection between college education and what it means to be an ethical person. I really enjoyed comparing college to the works of philosophers like Plato and leaders like MLK.
I learned a lot about philosophy and also improved my reading and writing skills.
A solid introduction to major philosophical works and how to analyze them.
Quality discussions with Dean Lewis, as well as my peers. It was a good opportunity to reflect on my time at Yale, and to truly appreciate what I had gained from an education here.
I think I developed a general understanding of what students should aim to learn in colleges as well as lots about philosophy.
I learned how to approach philosophy.
A great global understanding of philosophy. Less of a direct or contemporary focus on college education.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Less long readings that have little to do with the assignments.

Strengths are that the low workload makes the course less pressured and more enjoyable. Weaknesses are that sometimes the lecture can be a bit boring, however I often find the lectures very interesting and I enjoy them.
strength: it has a central focus/question and everything revolves around that.
I think the course could be approved by making more explicit links between The Republic and supplementary readings at education.

90% of the course readings/content are seemingly unrelated to college education or perhaps distantly related - when you enter the course expecting more relevant material, it makes the lectures and readings a bit of a drag
it was a good class

The strengths of the class could also be seen as the weaknesses of the class depending on what you want to get out of it and the reason you are taking it. The course has a very very manageable workload, which in turn means that unless you are putting in a very conscious effort, you will not feel super engaged with the materials and course itself. Nevertheless, the lectures are interesting and you will definitely learn things and become just generally better educated as a human being by taking this class, so it does not feel like a waste of a credit.
The course is great if you are interested in philosophy. The professor asked a lot of interesting questions that really got me thinking.

I enjoyed the examples Dean Lewis used from Yale his lectures because it felt very relevant to my experience. The course had an interesting main theme, but students did not seem very engaged during the majority of lectures. There were opportunities to participate, which helped engagement, but overall engagement was low.
This course was extremely succesful in keeping students engaged and active in discussion. There were no notable weaknesses.
An amazing professor and TA and very interesting material and discussion questions.
My discussion section was probably my favorite part of the course, it cleared up things that I missed during lectures. Weakness might be that its sometimes easy to miss things during lecture.

Great engaging lecture and exciting sectioon conversations. 

Both Dean Lewis and Rachel were great could not recommend more

Strengths: Very inclusive and interactive lecture style. The course being taught by the dean also makes the student feel more seen and included in the college environment especially considering the course is about the purpose of college.

Would probably flow better for students if the readings that were assignment were looked at more longterm and in depth (instead of a new article or text per lecture).
This course was amazing and I can think of no improvements.

It can be a little hard to improve your papers/assignments due to a lack of clear feedback, so youre kind of stuck with whatever grade you first get. Even in meeting with a TF theyre not super helpful in giving you ways to improve your paper

The course gets more and more engaging as time goes on. However, in the beginning, it's a little difficult to follow Greek philosophical readings and analyze them in the context of college education and its purposes. The lectures near the end were more contemporary and engaging. This course could be improved by mixing in old and new readings together rather than having one half being older readings and other half being newer readings.

I really enjoyed how interactive the lectures were. It made a big space feel small and engaging. I loved the class and I would barely change anything!! The only thing I would chance is the amount of information on the slides. There were some slides for which I couldnt write down all the information in time and some where I felt like there was not enough info!
I like the syllabus, content, and professorall were strengths.
I think that if the lectures were posted it would help a lot with getting a better understanding of what was discussed in class
no weaknesses, great class

Strengths: Covered an interesting and broad variety of material

Weaknesses: Lecture often seemed disconnected from assignments.
The strengths are the opportunities do discuss with classmates, and the opportunity to talk and get to know Dean Lewis himself.
This course could be a bit more interactive. The readings dont feel extremely helpful to understand lecture.
The course in general was interesting and the workload was fair.
More focus on contemporary college education

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It was a super interesting class to take that was a nice break from my normal STEM classes.
I totally would recommend this course to anyone who wants an interesting take on a philosophy class that does not add too much stress on your schedule.
No. Not interesting, not informative.
yes, only if you are interested in this central question

Not sure. Workload was "low" if you just don't do the readings as in depth as in other classes. It was advertised to me as a gut but my TA was a tough grader so I didn't end up doing as well as I wanted to despite putting a TON of time and effort into my essays
yes
I would recommend this course to somebody looking to take a gut humanities who has some interest in either ancient philosophy and/or structures of higher education teaching.
I would recommend this course to another student who was interested in reading philosophy.
I would not recommend this course to another student because the themes were not presented in a very interesting manner.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students, as it was a great way for me to develop my writing and analysis techniques.
100%. Not only is it an easier course, but Dean Lewis is an amazing lecturer and has very engaging discussion questions.
Yes its a course that educates you generally and makes you think about things in life and college that you might not think about otherwise.
Yes! Incredible learning experience on relevant subjects and also the chance to meet Dean Lewis.

Yes I would definitely recommend this course. Although the class is primarily filled with upperclassmen, as a first year I think it was a lot more valuable to me in my first semester than it would have been in my last. It allowed me to step into the college classroom and learn about myself while following along with the course lesson.
Yes!  This is an amazing course and Dean Lewis is an amazing professor.
Its a pretty chill 5th class, although the grading wasnt as easy as I expected it to be in the A/A- range

Yes! As a Yale student, it's very important to understand Yale as an institution, including its history, pedagogy, and intended purposes. This course was fundamental in grounding me as a student here and made me introspect what I came to Yale for more than what my high school self intended.
Yes. I think the information taught is very important for freshman embarking on their college experience. I would highly recommend.
Yes, absolutely, if they need another class or if they want to take a good introductory philosophy course.
yes, its applicable to every student and more about learning and deep thinking than grades or memorizing
Yes, if youre interested in a light course that introduces you to numerous philosophical theories throughout history.
Yes, It is a good class with interesting readings and discussions and not too much work.
I would recommend this course. I think it can get you to think about your college experience more actively and I believe is a good introduction or look into philosophy in an accessible way.
Yes, absolutely!
I would definitely recommend it; its generally a low stress environment and if you have a great TA like I did, the discussion sections can be very enjoyable.
No, grading was pretty strict with essays.
Yes this is a great course to expose you to a bunch of relevant philosophy for thinking about character, community, and education
